clinical_study.brief_title: Compression Ultrasonography in Non-high Probability of Deep Vein Thrombosis
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of the Predictive Value of Compression Venous Ultrasound by the Emergency Physician for Excluding the Diagnosis of Proximal Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in Patients With Non-high Clinical Pretest Probability

brief_summary.textblock: Compression ultrasound is commonly used in emergency department. Accuracy to rule out deep vein thrombosis is excellent but lower then Ddimer assessment which is actually gold standard. With progress in formation of emergency physicians (EP), quality of material used, the investigators hypothesize that compression ultrasound can rule out deep vein thrombosis in case of non high probability, as standard care and DDimer assay.

primary_outcome.measure: Negative predictive value of compression ultrasound for diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis
primary_outcome.time_frame: The measurement is assessed during ED stay or in 5 days if DD is positive with no DVT in compression ultrasound

arm_group.arm_group_label: Patient with clinical suspicion of deep vein thrombosis

intervention.arm_group_label: Patient with clinical suspicion of deep vein thrombosis

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- adult patient
- Patient presenting to the emergency department with clinical suspicion of DVT (i.e. pain and/or lower extremity edema).
- Patient with a non-high probability according to the modified Wells score, i.e. a score of 0 or 1
- Subject with a social health insurance plan
- Subject able to understand the objectives and risks of the research and to give a signed and dated informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient with suspected pulmonary embolism
- Patient with a high probability of DVT
- Impossible to perform a whole leg doppler ultrasound within 5 days
- Pregnant or breast-feeding woman, on patient's declaration
- Subject under court protection
- Subject under guardianship or curatorship
